channel.title: Brooklyn on Gourmand Syndrome
channel.description: Recent content in Brooklyn on Gourmand Syndrome

item.title: Din Soup Dumplings
item.description: We had some tickets to attend one of those Fever “Candlelight” concert events that was located at a church right next to the “Court St” R-stop in Brooklyn. There was not too many options in terms of food within close vicinity. I looked at the prices for this soup dumpling place, and to my surprise, Din Soup Dumplings seemed not bad. My partner was also in a dumpling mood, so it was convenient to go check this place out. This place is located right across the street from the church on the second level above another Chinese restaurant. We were able to walk in without reservations for 2 at around 5:30 PM on a Friday.

item.title: The River Cafe
item.description:
We finally made it to The River Cafe, which was a restaurant we wanted to go for a while. This restaurant sits right next to the East River, right under the Brooklyn Bridge. We made a reservation for a table of 7 at 5 PM on a Friday night. The dinner consists of primarily 3 courses, which has a fixed price of $195.

The River Cafe has 1 Michelin Star and first received it in 2010.

item.title: Gage and Tollner
item.description: Gage and Tollner has been on my list for quite a while now. I was casually browsing for restaurants with baked alaska, and this had shown up high on people’s list. Whenever I had tried to look at reservations, it was pretty booked. I was very lucky to have found an open reservation for 2 at 5 PM on a Sunday the night before. So how did it go?

item.title: Hanon
item.description: Hanon is located in the North Williamsburg area and is literally across the street on Union St. from the Metropolitan G stop and diner. It has been awarded the Michelin 2021 Bib Gourmand award. It originated in Kamakura, Japan in the summer of 2018. I hadn’t heard about this restaurant much at all and stumbled onto this through Yelp’s Hot & New filters. I wanted to try this restaurant out because the pictures of the udon sets look quite interesting, and the price point was pretty reasonable.

item.title: Republic Latin Fusion
item.description: North Williamsburg just keeps on growing and gentrifying. I had lived here when I first moved to NYC, and 5+ years later, there are even more restaurants within such a small area. Similar to Manhattan, many restaurants are rotating ownership and leases. This restaurant is a relatively new latin fusion restaurant that had opened back in September 2021. It sits very close to McCarren park a few doors away from one of my favorite cheese steak places, Federoff’s Steaks. Because we were done with our errands very early, we were able to walk in easy at 4:30 PM on a Sunday.

item.title: Aska
item.description: For my partner’s birthday, I decided on this 2 Michelin Star restaurant located in the Williamsburg area. What appealed to me originally about this was that it was not just another French restaurant. French cuisine is great, but there are so many high end French restaurants around the city. Perhaps I am getting a little burnt out of having the same French tastes over and over, so I wanted something that was less normal. I’ve never really had high end Scandinavian, so I thought today could be a good day. And to add, I had heard that they have non-alcoholic (juice) pairings, so I was excited to check this out.

item.title: Bacchus
item.description: We have not tried too many Brooklyn restaurants near the Barclays Center area for quite some time due to the pandemic. On this early brisk and semi-cold night, we had an interactive theater outing over at the One Hanson Place building in Brooklyn. After the event was over, a friend that we met at the event impromptly invited us to meet his friend at this restaurant. This was less than a mile away, and since we didn’t have other plans, we decided to try it out.

item.title: Andrea's Chicken
item.description: My partner is fanatical about ceviche, and I am fanatical about lomo saltado. Our level of comparison is Mario’s in Los Angeles, and there has yet been a tolerable comparison to that so far. There are not too many Peruvian options in the Williamsburg area. We’ve been to Chimu Bistro which was decent, and Llama Inn was a little too upscale. On this super sunny and muddy day after getting my hair chopped and despite all the plethora of options for anything but Peruvian, we decided to check out this restaurant based on recommendations. This is the second location of this restaurant, the first being in Maspeth.

item.title: Dokebi
item.description:
Summary

This Korean BBQ restaurant has been in North Williamsburg for a while. I’ve always wanted to go to this, but prior to the pandemic, it was always easier to go to Koreatown since I was always in Manhattan. We arrived here at an early rainy Sunday afternoon. They follow COVID protocol very well, and there were very few people inside. The waitress took our temperature and address as usual, and then we were seated after. The tables are separated by plastic guards. Let’s move onto the food.

item.title: Cafe Mogador
item.description:
Summary

To the outside world, the pandemic is wreaking havoc like wildfire. However for me personally, the only difference is that people are much more careful about cleanliness. In North Williamsburg, the brunch hipster spots are still thriving, and as you can imagine are very meticulous to avoid any type of spread.

Cafe Mogador has been one of those frequent brunch places that many flock to for weekend brunch. This is not the first time I’ve been here as I’ve always been neutral, but at least this time, I’ve taken pictures of some of the food.

item.title: Westlight
item.description:
Summary

Westlight sits on the 22nd floor of the William Vale hotel in North Williamsburg. When you enter the lobby of the hotel, there is a line to the right that directs you to board the elevator. Upon arrival, the host will seat you on 1 of 2 floors. The 1st floor might be for reservations and has a waiter, whereas the 2nd floor might be for walk-ins. The 2nd floor has a fake grassy area with some patio tables/chairs, and you don’t get waiter service. You order your drinks and food at the bartender, and they will bring out the food to your table when it’s ready. Keep in mind that we’re still under COVID restrictions, so no indoor dining. The host brought us outside on the 1st floor and seat us in a 2-seater that overlooks west towards the Manhattan skylines. It’s simply breathtaking especially on this cooler day of the summer in the core afternoon.

item.title: Aurora
item.description:
Summary

It’s been difficult to restart eating out again. Usually we just resort to delivery or takeout from various places nearby. However, it seems that many restaurants that are trying to outlast the pandemic by coming up with ideas to do the outdoor dining experience. Some restaurants don’t have a real patio, and you’re seated outside on the sidewalk within reach of people. And some restaurants like this one have a legit patio experience away from bystanders without worry.

item.title: High Lua Vietnamese Kitchen
item.description:
Summary

As usual, the North Williamsburg area is a pretty hot spot for restaurants to eat at. I had lived in this area for about 2 years, but I still come back time to time to get a haircut. Usually after the haircut, I’ll check out something. I’ve been looking for a decent pho place that is close enough to me such that I don’t have to travel to Flushing.

item.title: Kor Tor Mor
item.description:
Summary

What’s nice about Thai food is they are rarely bad, and they are very consistent even at different restaurants. We were in Cobble Hill after an errand, and this place was relatively close by and open for a late afternoon dinner.

We got 2 different Thai teas. The first was the regular Thai tea and the other is Lychee Thai tea. Both were pretty good. The lychee might be sweet for some, but it tastes literally like the fruit.

item.title: Zen Yai Pho Noodle Bar
item.description:
Summary

Pho vietnamese restaurants are generally pretty scarce in the city compared to Los Angeles. If you do find one, they usually don’t give you all the fixins and are timid about their offerings. In Los Angeles, I used to go to a restaurant called Phorage pretty frequently where their broth was very rich, and their meats were rare but tender. So how would this compare?

We started off with thai tea and matcha thai. The primary difference other than the higher cost is that the matcha thai tea has a bunch of matcha powder that kind of counters the sweetness of the thai tea by making it more dull but in a good way. It was actually pretty interesting comparing the 2.

item.title: La Cafette
item.description:
Summary

This restaurant has been on my list for a while. Before I moved out of North Williamsburg, I wanted to eat something with pork. Unfortunately at the time, they were closed on a Tuesday for whatever reason, so I did not have the opportunity to try this place until today.

The ambiance is a dimly lit romantic setting right near the corner of Havenmayer. There were a lot of candles all over, and the tables were pretty close to each other reminding me of my time in Paris. Keeping in mind that I am getting over a slight head congestion, my tastebuds might be a little on the dull size.

item.title: Paulie Gee's Slice Shop
item.description:
Summary

This is Paulie Gee’s sliced pizza. You can order a whole pie if you want. All in all though, I think Vinnie’s in Brooklyn is better.

The pepperoni pizza was good but not great for slice. If you come here expecting a similar crust to what the original Paulie Gee’s serves, prepare to be disappointed. The crust is not that great compared to a lot of NYC sliced pizza places.

item.title: Paulie Gee's
item.description:
Summary

Came here around 5:30 PM on a Saturday, and the wait was quoted 60 minutes. In reality, it was just 45 minutes, so it wasn’t too bad.

The pizza itself is similar to Roberta’s. The pizza dough is pretty fluffy, and it tastes pretty good.

The Benny Gee had much better taste than Ricotta Be Kiddin Me. The ricotta pizza was more salty, but the Benny Gee definitely had a better well rounded profile.

item.title: Dinosaur BBQ
item.description: Dinosaur “Bar-B-Que” is a New York state BBQ set fo restaurants that first opened in 1983 as a concession stand near Albany, NY for bikers. Since, they’ve expanded to a few more locations, including upstate NY as well as NYC. We’ve been to the Brooklyn location a few years ago, and we remembered it being pretty good. To relive our memories, we decided to visit again on a Sunday afternoon. We were able to walk-in at 4 PM without wait, though there were some logistical issues that did surface when we dined.

item.title: Oxomoco
item.description:
Summary

This apparently received a coveted 1 Michelin Star at this time of writing.

Went here for brunch, and I’d love to go back to try the dinner. Just like Casa Enrique, I find it pretty good but pricey for what you get.

The horchata was tasty, but does not beat those horchata machines back in LA. Also, it was loaded with ice, so the amount of liquid you get is pretty small for $6.

item.title: Di an Di
item.description: The pho was ok, and so was the dried vermicelli. It’s a bit expensive for what you get, but also not bad. I probably would still prefer to go to other Vietnamese places, though good Vietnamese places are hard to find in Manhattan. The decor is nice, but food wise - if anyone likes this place, I don’t trust their palette.

item.title: Chimu Bistro
item.description: The ceviche was good, but the lomo saltado was surprisingly pretty good. Beef slices were tender.

item.title: Brooklyn Banh Mi
item.description:
Best banh mi I’ve had so far in New York. Cheap too.

But this place is CLOSED.

item.title: Blanca
item.description: In my first visit to Blanca back in September 2018, I was a solo diner and had just moved to New York City pretty recently. I wrote down, “Really good. Definitely get the drink pairing. Michelin 2 star. $300 per person including drinks.” The vibe and space was absolutely fantastic. I then met my partner, and the pandemic arrived. Blanca shutdown and just simply never reopened until a few weeks ago. Knowing how high in demand this restaurant was in the past, I decided to take my partner to this restaurant to re-live the experience again.

item.title: Delaware and Hudson
item.description: 2016 and 2017 Michelin 1 star. Tasting only for dinner. Atlantic food. Fantastic.

item.title: Greenpoint Fish and Lobster
item.description: Surprisingly good. The oyster shuckers did a good job keeping it juicy. Happy hour is cheap!

item.title: Cape House
item.description: Scallops and clam strips were good. Pickles were salty not sour.

item.title: Sunken Hundred
item.description:
Good restaurant. I like the spanish octopus, fish churros, and pork chop.

Unfortunately, it’s CLOSED.

item.title: Wanpaku
item.description: Decent ramen in the Greenpoint area.

item.title: Yuji Ramen
item.description: Ramen omakase. Really good. Everything is homemade. $130 per person.

item.title: Ryujin Ramen
item.description: It’s just ok. I’d go to other ramen places over this.

item.title: Ichiran
item.description: This is an updated review for the Midtown / Times Square (Theater District) location for Ichiran. I had been to the original Bushwick location years ago, and I didn’t take pictures nor remembered much about it. The only thing I wrote down was it was a much better version of Shinsengumi. Shinsengumi was a popular Torrance (California) restaurant that served hakata style ramen. They also allowed you to select your flavor profiles, and it was far less busy than Ichiran.

item.title: Champion
item.description: There are actually a lot of locations for this. I think Vinnie’s way better in the north Williamsburg area.

item.title: Roberta's
item.description: Pizza is pretty good and cheap. Their beer list is pretty good.

item.title: Vinnie's
item.description: My cousin Vinnie’s place is the best. Love the cali burger.

item.title: Olmsted
item.description: Was pretty good surprisingly, though the portion sizes were way too small. Ended up eating some rhubarb pie afterwards.

item.title: Leuca
item.description: New American centric. Cheap but not too expensive. In the Vale hotel.

item.title: Lucky Luna
item.description:
Got the pozole here which seems to be uncommon here in NYC. Spicy, but pretty good.

Too bad it’s CLOSED.

item.title: Llama Inn
item.description: This place was pretty good. It’s expensive sorta, but the lomo saltado was decent.

item.title: Bulbap Grill
item.description: This place was ok in Greenpoint. The soondobu was probably the better thing to get. They do have Korean style tacos.

item.title: Kichin
item.description: Decent bibimbap, but don’t go out of your way for this.

item.title: Dotory
item.description: Really good. I like their kimchi jigae because it’s super sour. Don’t get their soondobu. It sucks.

item.title: Okonomi
item.description: Really good Japanese breakfast place.

item.title: Lilia Caffe
item.description: Had to make reservations 30 days ahead of time. Food was decent. Interior is nice. Homemade pasta. Good date place. Slightly overrated. Very similar to Culver City Bucato (before it shuttered) a few years ago.

item.title: Gran Sasso
item.description: Really good. Homemade pasta, and steak was good. Wasn’t that expensive either. Has been renamed to Scriptum Brooklyn. Not sure if it’s the same place.

item.title: Emmy Squared
item.description:
Summary

I’ve been here numerous times to both the East Village and Manhattan locations, and they have consistently delivered pretty well within expectations.

The fried chicken sandwich is delectable. It was really good and pretty spicy with the right kick.

The Le Big Matt is like pretty big too. The cheese is super melty which makes it a little messy but pretty delicious.

The Roni Supreme is by far my favorite. It’s exactly what the description says. Be warned, it’s a little on the salty side.

item.title: Rider
item.description: Was actually really good, and was one of the first places I went to when I moved here.

item.title: Daly Pie
item.description: Got the rhubarb, and it was pretty good. I love them rhubarb pies.

item.title: Ample Hills Creamery
item.description: Got the pistachio brittle, and it was mediocre. I think Van Leeuwen is better.

item.title: Patisserie Tomoko
item.description:
They have dessert tasting menus. The black sesame is good.

The black sesame ice cream is amazing. Not too sweet, but also very punchy in flavor. Delicious.

The green tea roll was very good. The center was cold and creamy, but not too sweet.

The pumpkin tart was really good too. The crust was flaky similar to an egg tart.

item.title: Tobys Estate
item.description: This is pretty good. The Brooklyn Blend beans are good for cold brew and hot.

item.title: Gimme Coffee
item.description: It’s ok. Beans are not as good as Toby’s. It’s closed though.

item.title: Brooklyn Ball Factory
item.description: Decent place.

item.title: Mountain Province
item.description: I like their latte.

item.title: Yaso Tangbao
item.description: This place was pretty good for the price. The soup dumplings had the authentice black vinegar sauce with ginger. They were open on Thanksgiving.

item.title: M Noodle Shop
item.description: Terrible but cheap Chinese. The pork chop on top of rice was terrible.

item.title: Vanessas Dumpling House
item.description: Pretty good. Pass on the beef noodle though.

item.title: Pearls
item.description: Caribbean “pita” pocket stuff is pretty good. The chips with guac and shrimp +1.

item.title: Juanchi
item.description: Pretty good burger if your’e in the area.

item.title: Mister Dips
item.description:
This place was pretty good. It’s in that Vale hotel.

The waffle fries were good as well as the soft serve.

item.title: Pops
item.description:
One of the best fast-foody burger places in Brooklyn. Cheap, quality, and delish. Cholo is where it’s at. They use Pat La Frieda meats for their burgers, and it’s not too expensive.

Too bad it’s PERMA closed due to rent increase. In place of it is a sex shop.

item.title: Blue Collar
item.description: This place is worse than Pops. Too bad Pops closed down.

item.title: Moe's Doughs Donut Shop
item.description: So apparently, the head baker from Peter Pans down the street now works here. Regardless, the ECLAIR with the white filling in the middle is really really good. It’s not too sweet and CHEAP @ $1.50. Better than DKs. Skip the cake donuts of course.

item.title: House of Small Wonder
item.description:
This place is cash-only and has Japanese style breakfasts. Think tomato sauce on top of an omelette that has fried rice in it.

I got the hamburger steak of course. Decent. Decor is interesting.

item.title: Sunday in Brooklyn
item.description:
The Korean looking sammich was good, and so was the biscuits and gravy. Can you tell I’m a biscuits and gravy kinda person?

If there’s a line outside, check the bar inside. Might be able to walk in and sit there instead of waiting for a table.

item.title: Le Barricou
item.description: Came here for brunch. Got the duck hash, and it was pretty good. Service was slower than a snail crawling across the sidewalk.

item.title: Jimmy's Diner
item.description: Their biscuits and gravy with eggs was surprisingly good. Cheap but cash only.

item.title: Reunion
item.description: Their shakshooka is really good! Coffee is good too but definitely get the shakshooka if eating.

item.title: Egg
item.description: I liked it. A little pricey but good stuff.

item.title: John Brown Smokehouse
item.description: For whatever reason, the brisket was dry even though it’s recommended by Yelpers. The pastrami was also dry and overly salty. Generally the BBQ was bad. Maybe it was just this one time, not sure.

item.title: Hometown BBQ
item.description:
Summary

Been here a few times already now. It’s always a trek to get here. It’s about a mile away from the Smith G stop subway station. If you go walking at night, it’s a little sketchy at times.

The wait for the food on a prime time Saturday night can be up to an hour if the line starts near the band. If you want to avoid the line, come here circle 11 AM on a Sunday.

item.title: Fette Sau
item.description: BBQ is really good. Better than Mighty Quinn’s.

item.title: Spritzenhaus 33
item.description: Crowded AF. Really noisy, bartenders slow AF. Standard Biergarten is better as well as the other one in Billsburg.

item.title: Hotel Delmano
item.description: Cool place. They have food. Not too expensive. Right next to the water sorta in Williamsburg.

item.title: Elsa
item.description: Cool vibe. Good place to take people who live in Carroll Gardens area circa Smith St.

item.title: Fresh Kills
item.description: Decent stop for a drink before going elsewhere.

item.title: Post Office
item.description:
Cool place for whiskeys.

But it’s CLOSED.

item.title: Golden Years
item.description: Fried chicken sandwich was ok. Has a kick to it just like every fried chicken sandwich place. Cash only though. Don’t think I’d care to come back.

item.title: Troost
item.description: Cool divey spot. Cheap drinks. Lots of gin/tequila based cocktails. They occasionally have random small bands.
